awd_titl_txt: Developing Tree-Ring Based Streamflow Reconstructions for Large and Complex River Basins
awd_abstract_narration:
This project analyses the use of tree-ring derived streamflow information as an alternative technique to develop long-term records of river streamflow in temperate, complex river-basins.  Better and longer stream-flow records will help improve water resource management in large and complex watersheds experiencing and anticipating drought and water supply shortages.  In places where measured runoff records are limited, tree-ring based streamflow records can be used to understand the range of possible variability and to therefore improve water management planning and modeling.  This technique has mostly been used in semi-arid environments with relatively simple surface hydrology.  This project implements and analyses tree-ring based streamflow modeling techniques in temperate, hydrologically complex watersheds, to assess its effectiveness, and thereby improving drought mitigation in those basins.  This research will be conducted in collaboration with local stakeholders, and has the potential to inform local water management plans, fish conservation, and ongoing negotiations of water and resource rights. Technical workshops will build capacity for stakeholders to incorporate these new records into their own decision-making framework.  The project provides field and academic learning opportunities for an undergraduate student and supports the continuing research program of an early career female Postdoctoral Research Scientist. 

Large temperate watersheds are increasingly susceptible to the impacts of drought, but their complex hydrology complicates the application of flow reconstruction to water supply forecasting.  To accomplish meaningful tree-ring modeling in these basins, where multiple, shifting sources of runoff across several sub-basins mean that water management is reliant on seasonal streamflow information, this project directly targets drought-season runoff and decomposes the study watershed basin into independent main-stem and sub-basin reconstructions.  This project will compare a large network of tree-ring chronologies with meteorological, gridded climate, and instrumental streamflow data from the basin main-stem and sub-basin gauges.  Using these relationships as a guide for targeted chronology resampling, paleoclimate reconstructions of past summer runoff and drought will be developed for each basin spanning the last several centuries.  During the summer season a combination of snowmelt, air temperatures, and rainfall determine streamflow and each of these factors is also linked to radial tree growth.  The reconstructions will be statistically compared against independent estimates of past hydro-climate variability, model simulations, and independently developed climate fields to determine whether recent droughts have been exceptional in the last several centuries, and whether medium- and long-term internal hydro-climate variability contains a forced anthropogenic signal.  Updated chronologies will permit examination of a recent extreme drought event and estimates of the probability of similar-magnitude droughts in the future.  By targeting one of the most complex river basins in the world, the Fraser River Basin (FRB), this project provides a sound framework for enhancing water management in temperate watersheds in the United States and around the globe.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Fraser River Basin is the seventh largest watershed in North America by annual discharge, sustaining some of the world's most biodiverse and pristine wildlands, the most productive salmon fishery on earth, and the food and economic sovereignty of numerous Indigenous communities and First Nations.  Human-caused climate change has already modified the surface hydrology of the basin, leading to droughts that appear unprecedented in the context of the short instrumental period, but that are expected to become longer, more frequent, and more severe in the future.  However, due to the limitations of the observational record, the long-term stationarity of hydrology and climate in this major North American watershed remains poorly understood.  In this project, we developed new tree-ring data and a novel suite of seasonal streamflow reconstructions for the Fraser River and its sub-basins that span the last several centuries.  Large, hydrologically complex watersheds in temperate environments represent a frontier in dendrohydrology, which has traditionally been carried out in semi-arid zones where the trees are strongly moisture-limited and their annual ring widths reflect integrated flows over the year. Our research extended dendrohydrology into one of the most hydroclimatically, biogeographically, and topographically complex temperate watersheds on Earth. 

We used a network of tree-ring data to develop paired flood- and drought-season reconstructions for eleven sub-basins, the first of their kind. The reconstructions explicitly targeted management-relevant flood (spring) and drought seasons within each basin and are examined in tandem to provide an expanded assessment of extreme events across the Fraser River Basin. We found that past high flood-season flows had greater magnitude and occurred in more consecutive years than during the observational record alone. Early 20th century low flows in the drought season were especially severe in both duration and magnitude in some sub-basins relative to recent dry periods. Our Fraser sub-basin reconstructions provide long-term benchmarks for the natural flood and drought variability before anthropogenic forcing.  We also find that instrumental streamflow records do not accurately reflect the long-term natural hydrological variability in the Fraser's primary headwater basin.  We are however able to detect an intensification of spring season flood flows.  The clustering of compound high flood and low drought-season runoff has also increased over the recent decades relative to the long-term context provided by our tree-ring reconstructions.  These reconstructions demonstrate that the instrumental streamflow records upon which current management is based likely underestimate the full natural magnitude, duration, and frequency of extreme seasonal flows in the Fraser River Basin and the potential severity of future anthropogenically forced and compound flood-drought events. 

Tree-ring data developed in this project also provide new insights into the exceptional 2021 summer heatwave that struck the broader Pacific Northwest. We used tree-ring records to show that summer temperatures in 2021 and the rate of summertime warming during the last several decades are unprecedented in the last millennium for the entire Pacific Northwest region.  We further used climate model simulations to show that, in the absence of committed efforts to reduce anthropogenic emissions, there is a rapidly increasing risk that this region will experience 2021-like extreme summer temperatures in the near future, with a 50% chance of yearly occurrence by 2050.

This research provides the long-term context for modern and future climate variability in the Fraser River basin that is critical for adaptive water management, the survival of endangered Pacific salmon populations, ecological resilience, the livelihoods of First Nations, adaptation to extreme events, and ongoing conservation and management of water and other natural resources. This research also supported the education, training, and career development of a graduate student and an early career postdoctoral researcher.
